metadata.synopsis: A newsman (James Franciscus) works with a blind puzzle-solver (Karl Malden) to catch a killer with mixed-up chromosomes.

reviews: The film is an entertaining and involving reminder of why Argento has long been recognized as one of the masters of the giallo thriller.
Argento tamps down his more extreme stylist instincts to fashion a somewhat more conventional mystery, albeit with unconventional characters.
Argento reportedly doesn't care much for this picture, but that shouldn't stop the rest of us from enjoying its twisty tale.
Argento is quoted as saying this wasn't his favorite film creation. Well, never mind that. I like Malden and Franciscus and it's fun watching them fight for justice in an Italian murder mystery.

The film's 9 disparate leads will eventually be synthesised, but on the way there are a lot of blind alleys, false trails & red herrings, as much obscuring as revealing the solution in a manner that recalls the parable of the blind men & an elephant.
For all of Argento's virtuosity, he's no master of suspense or even tension. He's a showman and a stylist and his set pieces are pulp art pieces...
A tall and slimmer Karl Malden stands out, but even with a rooftop chase, the conclusion and revelation are abrupt.

if it is Argento's weakest early effort, it is only because he was still trying to find his voice, experimenting with different techniques and gradually learning just how far he could push the envelope.
Italian 'giallo' thriller by horrormeister Dario Argento.
Dario Argento giallo is the cat's meow.
...highly unlikely to appeal to anyone other than the most ardent Argento fan, and even those folks will be hard-pressed to find anything here worth embracing.
Moderately effective, stylish early giallo from Argento
